abstract: Sergey Brin used it to find his hotel in Davos. Eric Schmidt thinks it is going to bring in advertising dollars. Google is planning to challenge it with its own cellphone software. What is it? The iPhone.
snippet: Sergey Brin used it to find his hotel in Davos. Eric Schmidt thinks it is going to bring in advertising dollars. Google is planning to challenge it with its own cellphone software. What is it? The iPhone.
lead_paragraph: For a company that is busy building its own cellphone operating system, Google shared a lot of love for the iPhone on its earnings-related conference call today. The most heartwarming story came from Sergey Brin, the company’s co-president, who said that he uses an iPhone himself. He described the value of the My Location feature of Google Maps on the iPhone, which can figure out (more or less) where you are even though the iPhone can’t receive G.P.S. navigational signals.

headline.main: Sergey Brin’s iPhone Adventure in Davos

abstract: The deathwatch on the Reddy Ice deal ended Thursday. In anticipation of the Feb. 5 termination date on its deal, Reddy Ice, a maker of packaged ice, announced that it had agreed to terminate its agreement to be acquired by affiliates of GSO Capital Partners. In connection with the termination, GSO agreed to pay Reddy Ice $21 million in cash on Feb. 5 — the self-same termination date. In addition, Reddy Ice agreed to pay up to $4 million of fees and expenses incurred by GSO and its consultants in connection with the failed transaction.

lead_paragraph: DURING this season of economic alarm and political choice, “Judgment” (Portfolio, $26.95), by Noel M. Tichy and Warren G. Bennis, could not be more timely. Americans live in a democracy, cherish checks and balances, and remain skeptical of concentrated power. abstract: A happiness expert talks about why happiness at work matters.
snippet: A happiness expert talks about why happiness at work matters.
lead_paragraph: Today’s guest post is written by Gretchen Rubin, who writes the popular blog, The Happiness Project. Ms. Rubin is also working on a book of the same title, which will be a memoir of the year she spent testing every principle, tip, theory and scientific study about happiness she could find, whether from Aristotle, St. Therese, Martin Seligman or Oprah. Prior to her foray into the world of happiness, Ms. Rubin had an impressive career as a lawyer, including clerking for a Supreme Court justice, Sandra Day O’Connor. She is also the author of three books, Power Money Fame Sex: A User’s Guide, Forty Ways to Look at JFK and Forty Ways to Look at Winston Churchill.

headline.main: Happiness at Work: Does it Matter?

abstract: UNITED ADDS A CHECKED-BAG FEE Saying that it was offering customers a “new, simplified checked-bag policy,” United Airlines said that it would charge $25 to check a second bag, starting May 5, for customers who travel domestically on advance purchase nonrefundable fares. The vast majority of coach passengers buy such fares, as opposed to the more expensive, fully refundable walk-up fares. United said the fee would generate more than $100 million a year “in cost savings and new revenue.” Most competitors allow coach passengers to check a second bag without charge. United’s fee policy also applies to travel to and from Canada; San Juan, P.R.; and St. Thomas, V.I., for tickets purchased starting this week. Passengers with Premier status or higher in United’s Mileage Plus frequent-flier program and those with Silver status or higher in the Star Alliance program will be exempt from the fee.

abstract: For two decades, Carl C. Icahn has been among the most visible of rabble-rousing investors, garnering attention from the press for nearly every investment he makes. abstract: Australia’s central bank raised its benchmark interest rate by a quarter- point to an 11-year high, saying a “significant slowing in demand” is needed to cool the fastest inflation since 1991. The bank increased the target for the overnight cash rate to 7 percent and the bank’s governor, Glenn Stevens, said annual inflation, which has overshot the bank’s target, might accelerate further before moderating in 2009. Core inflation in Australia has breached the central bank’s 2 percent to 3 percent target for two consecutive quarters, forcing the Australian bank to raise rates for the third time in six months.

abstract: The Monsanto Company said Japan, the Philippines and Taiwan had approved imports of its first new genetically modified soybeans in more than a decade. The new plants, which resist Roundup weed killer, won regulatory approval in the United States and Canada in July, the company said. The product remains under review in the European Union, China and other export markets, Monsanto said.

abstract: The German truck maker MAN said its profit increased by 33 percent in the fourth quarter, powered by strong demand for its commercial vehicles, and forecast that earnings would continue to rise this year. MAN, which is based in Munich, said it earned 331 million euros ($490 million) in the October-December quarter, up from 248 million euros a year earlier. Total group sales rose 35 percent, to 5.23 billion euros ($7.7 billion) from 3.88 billion euros a year earlier. Sales of commercial vehicles rose 42 percent, to 3.6 billion euros ($5.3 billion). MAN said its fourth-quarter operating profit was up 78 percent, to 631 million euros ($935 million) from 354 million euros a year earlier.

abstract: France Telecom said 2007 net profit rose 52 percent on better margins and lower taxes, with its mobile phone businesses fueling sales. Net profit increased to 6.3 billion euros ($9.28 billion) from 4.14 billion euros a year earlier. The 2006 figure was reduced by a write-down of 2.8 billion euros for good will, but the rise in profit was attributed also to lower taxes and financial charges and improving margins. Revenue rose to 52.96 billion euros ($77.99 billion) from 51.7 billion euros in 2006, helped by growth in France Telecom’s mobile phone operations across Europe, Africa and the Middle East.

abstract: Diageo said it had abandoned a potential bid for the Swedish brand Absolut Vodka and formed a joint venture with the owners of a rival Dutch vodka, Ketel One. Diageo said that it would pay $900 million (611 million euros) in a deal with the Nolet family for ”perpetual exclusive global rights to sell, market and distribute” Ketel One vodka. The Nolet family, distillers since 1691, will continue to own the brand rights for Ketel One and the Nolet distillery in Schiedam in the Netherlands. That leaves three rivals — Pernod Ricard, Bacardi and Fortune Brands, the United States distributor of Absolut — in the auction, for Absolut’s owner, Vin & Sprit, which is being sold by the Swedish government. Analysts have estimated the sales price at $6.3 billion.

That leaves three rivals  Pernod Ricard, Bacardi and Fortune Brands, the United States distributor of Absolut  in the auction, for Absolut’s owner, Vin & Sprit, which is being sold by the Swedish government. abstract: Air Canada reported fourth-quarter profit of 35 million Canadian dollars ($34.8 million), reversing a year-earlier loss, helped by a stronger Canadian dollar and higher domestic demand. Net income was 35 cents a share, the airline said. A year earlier, Air Canada had a net loss of 144 million Canadian dollars. Revenue increased 3.7 percent, to 2.51 billion Canadian dollars ($2.5 billion). Air Canada, which generates a fifth of its revenue from flights to the United States, had been shifting capacity to domestic routes to avoid a slowdown in the United States. Air Canada’s stock rose 18 percent after the results were released.

abstract: Banco Santander said fourth-quarter profit fell 6 percent as the bank took a $1.08 billion write-down in its main United States investment, Sovereign Bancorp. Santander said quarterly net profit fell to 2.49 billion euros ($3.64 billion) from 2.65 billion euros ($3.87 billion) in the fourth quarter of 2006. With Sovereign shares down 50 percent over the past year, Santander is realizing a big paper loss on its 25 percent stake in the bank. Sovereign this year reported a $1.3 billion (890 million euro) net loss for all of 2007, partly as a result of fallout from the subprime lending crisis.

lead_paragraph: Banco Santander said fourth-quarter profit fell 6 percent as the bank took a $1.08 billion write-down in its main United States investment, Sovereign Bancorp. Santander said quarterly net profit fell to 2.49 billion euros ($3.64 billion) from 2.65 billion euros ($3.87 billion) in the fourth quarter of 2006. With Sovereign shares down 50 percent over the past year, Santander is realizing a big paper loss on its 25 percent stake in the bank. Sovereign this year reported a $1.3 billion (890 million euro) net loss for all of 2007, partly as a result of fallout from the subprime lending crisis.

headline.main: Spain: Bank Hurt by U.S. Subprime Fallout
headline.print_headline: Spain: Bank Hurt By U.S. Subprime Fallout

abstract: WestLB, hit by losses tied to bad trades and the subprime mortgage market, will reduce its work force by 25 percent  under a rescue plan forged with regulators.

headline.main: German Bank Gets $7.2 Billion Bailout

abstract: A small book publisher faces off against the titans in a Harry Potter copyright case.

lead_paragraph: On Friday, a lawyer named Anthony Falzone filed his side’s first big brief in the case of Warner Bros. Entertainment and J. K. Rowling v. RDR Books. Mr. Falzone is employed by Stanford Law School, where he heads up the Fair Use Project, which was founded several years ago by Lawrence Lessig, perhaps the law school’s best-known professor. Mr. Falzone and the other lawyers at the Fair Use Project are siding with the defendant, RDR Books, a small book publisher based in Muskegon, Mich. As you can see from the titans who have brought the suit, RDR Books needs all the legal firepower it can muster.

abstract: I leaped up from my desk vowing to commit the most sensational attack of revenge in the history of the personal computer industry.

lead_paragraph: AT high noon on a recent Monday, I leaped up from my desk vowing to commit the most sensational attack of revenge in the history of the personal computer industry. Just 72 hours earlier, I had taken delivery on a Dell Inspiron 1720 laptop loaded with Microsoft Windows Vista. It was already on the blink. I couldn’t open a Word document. I couldn’t run a Google search. I couldn’t even send e-mail. I vowed to shave Michael Dell and Bill Gates with a broken beer bottle.

abstract: How campaign donors can defy the odds of a classic economic theory.
snippet: How campaign donors can defy the odds of a classic economic theory.
lead_paragraph: TRADITIONAL economic models assume that people are self-interested in the narrow sense. If “homo economicus”  the stereotypical rational actor in these models  finds a wallet on the sidewalk, he keeps the cash inside. He doesn’t leave tips after dining in restaurants that he will never visit again. And he would never vote in a presidential election, much less make an anonymous donation of money or time to a presidential campaign.

headline.main: When Self-Interest Isn’t Everything

abstract: The European Union’s telecommunications commissioner said she would seek limits on the price Europeans pay to send short text messages when traveling outside their home countries, unless operators lower the charges by July. The commissioner, Viviane Reding, said the rates are four to five times domestic messaging rates. If prices were not reduced by July, Ms. Reding, left, said she would ask the European Parliament and Council of Ministers to enact price limits, which could take effect by the summer of 2009. Operators reacted coolly to her threat. Craig Ehrlich, the chairman of the GSM Association, which represents 700 mobile operators, said competitive pressure among operators was already bringing down prices, and further regulation was not needed.

abstract: The Kimberly-Clark Corporation, the maker of Huggies diapers and Scott paper towels, plans to build two plants in Peru as part of a plan to make the country its South American hub. lead_paragraph: The economic stimulus legislation approved by Congress on Thursday includes two provisions that would benefit businesses. The first raises  to $250,000 in 2008, from $128,000  the dollar amount of limits on expensing. The second allows for a one-year depreciation deduction of 50 percent of the cost of the property, in addition to regular depreciation on the remaining cost. Barbara Weltman, a lawyer and author of “J. K. Lasser’s Small Business Taxes, 2008,” provides examples of how both would work.

headline.main: Aid for Business in Stimulus Package

abstract: Wholesale prices rose at the fastest pace in a quarter-century, led by higher oil and wheat costs that are causing inflation. Producer prices climbed 3 percent in January from a year earlier, after a 2.6 percent gain in December, the Bank of Japan said. Consumer prices rose the most in almost a decade in December, which, combined with falling wages, drove household sentiment to a four-year low. The current-account surplus narrowed for the first time in a year in December as oil pushed the nation’s import bill to a record, a separate report showed. The gap shrank 4.7 percent to 1.69 trillion yen ($15.7 billion) from a year earlier, the finance ministry said.

lead_paragraph: If you spend too much time pointing and clicking just to read your Gmail on the Web, check out Google’s set of keyboard shortcuts. Log into your Gmail account, click the Settings link and go to the General tab to enable keyboard shortcuts. Click the Learn More link to see a list of what you can do on the keyboard  or just click Save Changes and then type a question mark to see a list pop up on screen. Once you learn them, keyboard shortcuts can save time and mouse work  for example, just type an exclamation mark to tag an open message as spam and remove it from your In box.

abstract: It’s that time of the year when velvet boxes get opened — perhaps with some candlelight and a fancy dinner, just to seal the deal — and the question gets popped. Frank Boroch, an analyst at Bear Stearns, suggested last week that a Feb. 14 merger announcement would play up the friendly aspects of any proposal, as opposed to the ugly situation with Delta’s previous suitor, an unabashedly hostile (and ultimately unsuccessful) US Airways.

lead_paragraph: The first wave of offshore outsourcing was in computer programming, sending software development and maintenance abroad, mainly to India. The next wave, well underway, is shipping back-office business tasks overseas, like finance, payroll, claims processing, procurement and the like. That’s business process outsourcing, or BPO, in nerd talk.

headline.main: Offshore Outsourcing’s Next Wave: How High?

lead_paragraph: In the 18 months or so that I’ve been covering Yahoo and its competitors here, I’ve run into a good number of dejected, demoralized Yahoo employees. I’ve also run into many who have mixed feelings — they love Yahoo, but think it was mismanaged — and many others who can’t say enough good things about the place. That includes many people who chose to leave — not because of ill will toward Yahoo but because their careers took them elsewhere.

headline.main: A Farewell Note From a Departing Yahoo

abstract: Let’s talk about health insurance for small business owners and the self-employed.
snippet: Let’s talk about health insurance for small business owners and the self-employed.
lead_paragraph: I’m often asked about where independent workers and other self-employed people can get health insurance. I would like to hear from you, readers, about how you get your insurance. What kinds of policies are you choosing, and why? Where do you get it? What does it cost? If you have a resource to share, do it in the comments. If you want to write a longer note about your personal experience, e-mail me at heymarci@nytimes.com using the words “health insurance” in the header. I won’t be able to reply directly to everyone, but I will read them all and promise to share what I learn in the column or blog.

headline.main: Friday’s Links: Health Insurance for the Self-Employed

abstract: The Fair Game column last Sunday, about loan losses at Citibank during the 1990 recession, misstated the history of stock prices for the bank’s parent, then called Citicorp. The stock traded as low as $11.125 in October 1990, not $1.39. After the Federal Reserve started cutting interest rates, the price rose to $15.625, not $2.50, by March 6, 1991; it climbed to $67.25, not $10, by the end of 1995. (The lower prices were for Travelers, a company that later merged with Citicorp.).

The part of me looking forward to it hopes that I get selected for a jury. The part of me that is anxious has been hustling to get ahead on work and dodging meeting requests so that I am free in case I am out of commission for a week or longer. (I know that I can defer the jury duty to a more convenient time, but I have already deferred once and, in truth, there aren’t more convenient times.)

headline.main: Off to Jury Duty

abstract: A $7.15 billion structured investment vehicle managed and sponsored by the British banking company Standard Chartered may default this week after failing to repay maturing debt, Standard & Poor’s said. The investment vehicle, Whistlejacket Capital, was put into receivership last week. It failed to pay notes due last Friday, S.& P. said, and will be in default if it fails to make a payment by Thursday, when a three-day grace period ends. Whistlejacket, based in the British Channel Islands, appointed receivers after a decline in the value of its holdings set into motion rules forcing it to wind down and prompted Standard Chartered to abandon a bailout it had proposed. Standard Chartered is pursuing a reorganization of Whistlejacket, S.& P. said, citing information from Deloitte & Touche, the company’s receiver.

abstract: Brazilian retail sales climbed 9 percent in December from December 2006, capping their best year since at least 2001 as record low borrowing costs stimulated consumer spending. Retail, supermarket and grocery store sales rose 9.6 percent last year, the biggest gain since the national statistics agency started the current series in 2001. “The sales that gained the most were those that depend on credit,” said Alex Agostini, chief economist at Austin Rating Serviços Financeiros in São Paulo. Sales of home appliances and furniture rose 15.4 percent in 2007, the national statistics agency said. Computer and office material sales increased 29.4 percent and vehicle sales jumped 22.6 percent.

abstract: Passenger traffic on domestic airlines rose in 2007, but worldwide growth in first- and business-class travel slowed.

lead_paragraph: CARRIER CUTS MILEAGE BENEFITS Starting in May, US Airways says, frequent-flier miles in its Dividend Miles program will be awarded based on the actual number of miles flown. The change affects passengers who fly short-haul trips of less than 500 miles, including those who use the US Air shuttle between New York and Boston and Washington. Under the previous policy, passengers were awarded a minimum credit of 500 miles a flight, which is standard practice in major airlines’ frequent-flier programs. US Airways also said that passengers who redeem miles for award travel within 14 days of departure would be changed a “quick-ticketing fee” of $50 a ticket. US Airways cited “record fuel prices and rising airline-related expenses” for the changes.

headline.main: Domestic Passenger Traffic Rose in 2007

abstract: Two short days on jury duty provide a slight inconvenience and a nice jolt of civic enthusiasm.
snippet: Two short days on jury duty provide a slight inconvenience and a nice jolt of civic enthusiasm.
lead_paragraph: After all my anticipation and anxiety, jury duty came and went in a flash. Day 1 was interesting. And short. I arrived at 60 Centre Street at 8:45 a.m. along with throngs of fellow citizens and took my seat. The clerks who run the jury process — two women so polished they could play their roles in “Jury Duty, the Movie” — began orientation with a list of rules. They sprinkled their instructions with more than a few well-placed one-liners. “Do not remove any articles of clothing below the waist.” “Never put your face to the water-fountain fixture. We have cups.” “Never abandon your possessions; we have had thefts.” My neighbor leaned in and whispered to me, “If they say it, it’s happened.” We bonded. She agreed to be the trusted buddy whom Clerk #1 advised us to find, available to watch my possessions should I need to use the restroom. I offered the same back.

headline.main: Jury Duty: It Came. It Went. I Served.

abstract: Editors and reporters who worked on The Times’s recent article about Senator John McCain answered questions.

lead_paragraph: A recent New York Times article examined a number of decisions by Senator John McCain that raised questions about his judgment over potential conflicts of interest. The article included reporting on Mr. McCain’s relationship with a female lobbyist whose clients often had business before the Senate committee led by Mr. McCain. Since publication of the article, The Times has received more than 2,000 comments, many of them criticizing the handling of the article. More than 4,000 questions were sent via e-mail to The Times on Thursday night and Friday. Editors and reporters who worked on the article answered some of the questions on Friday. To move directly to the most recent answer, click here.

snippet: The Chumby, a $179 squishy Internet-linked alarm clock, is touted as being an open hardware and software standard. It is not open to publishers unless they agree to share some of their advertising revenue with the gizmo’s maker.
lead_paragraph: I find Chumby fascinating for a lot of reasons. Meant to replace a clock radio, it is a $179 device with a Wi-Fi connection, a 3.5-inch touch screen and a squishy leather case. It displays various widgets with information pulled off the Internet, and it plays podcasts, Internet radio and some Web video. lead_paragraph: Over the last few months, we’ve had quite a debate in the comments here about the relative merits of Blu-ray, HD DVD and standard DVD discs. Some argue we don’t need discs at all because we’ll all be able to download movies. And others have suggested that the price of memory chips is falling so fast that we might still buy movies in stores, but they may come loaded on U.S.B. memory sticks or the sort of SD memory cards that go in digital cameras.

abstract: Golf is one of the few sports in which a weekend amateur player can make a shot as good as that of any given pro, especially on or around the greens.

lead_paragraph: I STRODE onto the tee box of the 18th hole at Emerald Dunes Golf Club in West Palm Beach, Fla., with a 25-mile-an-hour wind blistering my cheeks and an existential quandary befuddling my brain. My industrialist friend David Koch and I were embroiled in a best-ball match against two veteran professionals. After losing three straight holes on the front nine, we had battled back to tie the match with one hole to go. But all I could think about was a vintage B.C. comic strip.

abstract: ANOTHER FARE INCREASE Major airlines have again raised domestic fares, adding $10 to round-trip prices on most routes. The latest fare increase, the third this year, was initiated by United Airlines on Friday and matched the next day by the five other network carriers, said Rick Seaney, the chief executive of FareCompare.com. Mr. Seaney said that there would probably be some “competitive price jockeying” as airlines roll back the increase on various highly competitive routes, but that over all the higher fare should stick.

lead_paragraph: There is a lot of buzz these days about coworking (without the hyphen), a new movement — well chronicled in this recent New York Times article — in which people share a workspace to combat loneliness, forge a community and enjoy the creative sparks generated by like-minded people. But coworking is about much more than sharing a workspace. It is a global movement whose adherents follow certain principles (check out the terrific video at the bottom of this page), including environmental responsibility and a free exchange of ideas. Interestingly, these spaces are not usually run for a profit; they tend to be more mission-focused.

abstract: There was a time when commodities markets were viewed with deep suspicion by farmers, who saw speculators and gamblers manipulating the prices of crops to benefit themselves and steal from farmers. In 1874, one house of the Illinois legislature approved a bill to make it a crime to trade a futures contract unless the seller actually had possession of the crop. The Chicago Board of Trade managed to water down the law to bar the trading of options, but not futures, and thus stayed in business.
